comments.commentBody: Delicious, was a big hit at family Christmas Eve.  Needed longer than 4 hours to get slushy; would make it night before next time.

Bill B - I don't need anything more than you need. My simple point is that the US justce department has a demonstrated pattern of coerced confession and strong arm tactics. I have no reason to believe that the same weren't used for BNP. Also, my core point: that Iran hasn't been made to pay anything, remains unchallenged.

People and nations tend to take care of their own and not care as much about "others". Spain too did a lot of harm too to people in its colonies. But I agree with some comments that the hostages took jobs that included risks just like the soldiers. POW's have not been compensated for their time as captives except back pay, perhaps.

Ah, the weather, since you mention it. It is a balmy Christmas morning here in the Northeastern Megalopolis, fifty-eight degrees Fahrenheit as presently I write. The prognosticators say it will go as high as Route 66.

But as to whether this monetary award is good or bad, of course it could be better or worse. Maybe the French bank will have legal recourse to recoup some of its loss from Iranian assets, although the gnomes of Zurich will probably play some kind of shell game. I think, however, that the bank should suffer a substantial penalty.

Other than that, may Iran perish.

Sorry about the whether weather... I am always wrestling with that...sometimes I just don't feel like grabbing the dictionary.  I don't understand the statement "may Iran perish " though. Seems awfully uncalled for esp on Christmas. I am absolutely in favor of opening up relations with Iran. I think it will benefit everyone. As do all the companies that are now going in. Because doing good business is the best way to keep peace and respect. But that's really not what this article s about. Merry Xmas ...................

re, "I don't understand the statement "may Iran perish " though."

To start right at the beginning, the word "may" is a marker for the subjunctive. Many people (their numbers are legion) are not even aware that English has a subjunctive mood, or even that English has grammar at all.

The subjunctive in English has the same uses as in other European languages. It is used when making a hypothetical or conditional statement, or to express a wish, that something "ought" to be, and so forth.

"May Iran perish" expresses a wish that Iran should perish, that I would be pleased if Iran were to perish.

I hope this helps.

If I read this right, which many commenters didn't seem too, the money is coming from a $9 billion dollar penalty paid by a French bank that did business with Iran, Cuba and Sudan violating the sanctions. And the rest will be put into a victims compensation fund. So the US taxpayers aren't paying anything.... Now weather you think paying the money out is good or bad, that's another story.

MEK or MKO or NCRI have murdered and kidnapped Americans, taken American hostage, bombed American companies in Iran. Since there is no statute of limitation on murders and kidnappings, they must be tried, and punished for their crimes. The officials of NCRI are the same murderers. Just because they have changed their name in order to hide the heinous crimes committed against Americans, it doesn't absolve them. In this context, many Nazi murderers or collaborators or camp guards many of whom were 18 or 19 years when they were camp guards were arrested decades after the WWII even though they had lived peaceful lives and raised families.

The blood of Lt. Col. Louis Lee Hawkins, Col. Paul Shaffer and Lt. Col. Jack Turner, William Cottrell, Donald Smith, and Robert Krongard who were killed by MEK/MKO/NCRI members is not only on their hands, but also on the hands of lawmakers, the former officials of both parties, and former military officials who support the terrorist group. The lawmakers not only owe apologies to the families of the six Americans killed, but also must be held responsible for embracing the terrorists and letting the murderers go free.

Regarding Israel, pro-Israel lobbies, and pro-Israel Americans, they are actively involved in overthrowing the Iranian government by encouraging terrorist action inside Iran with the help of the Arab countries, etc. read the latest article on that.

those held in internment camps did receive reparations, though the figure was $20,000, not $4.4 million. and a citizen of a country with which we  are at war is not an innocent.

CTA=Chicago Transit Authority.

The SEP/OCT thing gave me some key crossings. It did make things easier for a Friday.
I don't think the SEP/OCT thingy was lame, mainly because I was fooled into thinking those two entries would be (XMAS) EVE and DAY, and had to do some fancy remedial footwork as a consequence.
Pretty good puzzle, but the SEP/OCT thing would have been lame for a Monday. Am I right in presuming that CTA stands for Chicago Transit Authority?

On step 4 place the last 3 dry ingredients into one bowl (flour, salt and baking powder) and sift into another bowl together. (DON'T SIFT WHEN MEASURING THEM, JUST PUT EM IN A BOWL). POUR buttermilk into a cup. Pour 1/2 of the sifted flour mix into the butter mix. Mix until just blended followed by 1/2 of buttermilk. Mix until just blended. Pour the remainder of the flour into the butter mixture and continue mixing. Add vinegar to buttermilk and pour into the bowl. Mix until just blended.
So I am just starting out baking and this is the first cake I'm making from scratch and I'm getting hung up on step 4 can someone please explain
These cookies are fabulous! They taste amazing and are stunning. Great, easy recipe.

It's easier to find all the mixups that take only one pour to fix:
ROYE -> ROEY, EOYR, REYO (all ways to pour tonic into the empty glass)
now from each of the level 1 messy states there are 3 possible moves, one of which is a fix and the other two of which make things worse, so there are 2 x 3 = 6 states that are "level 2 messy".

Nice! I think you've completely accounted for all of the "level 1 messy state" and "level 2" messy states.

Lev 0:1 (Everything's already in order/the Grinch hasn't woken up yet)
Lev 1: 3
Lev 2: 6

There's a cool pattern to your method that reminds me of how mathematicians study strategic games like chess and tic-tac-toe ("combinatorial games"): thinking about the possibilities as a branching tree where each fork is a decision of which of several possible moves to make next.

So far, your tree split once into 3 cases, and then each of those 3 cases split into 2 directions, giving you 6 new cases.

Great progress, and a really cool approach!

If you have 2 full glasses and one empty, and the ideal arrangement is Red Orange Empty (ROE), then there are 5 other possible arrangements (REO, OER, EOR, ERO, ORE); all arrangements take 1, 2, or 3 pours to fix. REO and EOR are "level 1 messy", OER and ERO are "level 2 messy" and ORE is the most messy, requiring 3 pours to fix.

If you have 3 full glasses and one empty, and the ideal arrangement is Red Orange Yellow Empty (ROYE), there are 23 other possible arrangements. I wonder if there is still one mixup that's messier than any other, or if there are multiple mixups that tie for messiest.
That's why nannies were born.

It's not so simple.
A relatively young power couple marrying may cause a tremendous degree of tension. Both are driven and pushing their careers. Any attempt at family or families might be a problem unless there is massive help and even for power couples, that might not be available at the beginning. Somebody usually has to make concessions. That might lead to divorce. An "unequal" marriage might have the concessions already built in.

A relatively older power couple or second marriage power couple, established in their careers and comfortable, that has a better chance of success.

All in all though, marriage is not about power or income but about "give and take". To live with someone, one has to make concessions, even with intellectual and career equals.
you are naive! Russia is forced to reposnd because of the aggressive moves of the West. It is not the other way around.
Ok. Let US be one more country without weapons.

Ever since Mr.Putin assumed the office of President of Russia, after serving as Prime Minister, he has been vigorously making moves to boost the image of Russia as a powerful country. Annexation of Crimea and his intervention in Georgia were done only in that direction. Probably, he believes that with military might, he may bring back the ghost of USSR.
USSR is history now. The dynamics of world politics has also changed. The world is no more polarized on the lines of communism and capitalism. Therefore, how much ever Mr.Putin may strive to build the image of Russia with bolstered military, I wonder not many countries would fear and support it. Today, the world is faced with an enemy who is terrorizing in the name of a religion, which promotes peace. The only aim of all the countries should be to wipe out this enemy. The need of the hour is cooperation of all countries and not advanced fighter jets and bombers.
Be it the U.S.A. or Russia, accumulation of military ware will not ensure long lasting peace. It may at best act as a deterrent. But the enemy, whether Islamic terrorists or others, will be watching for any slackness in security, to strike at the society and kill innocent people.
There are plenty of countries on this planet, which live peacefully with no big military to protect them. Both America and Russia should learn lessons from such countries.

America's "Industrial War Complex" seeks to justify an already incredibly bloated defense budget that offers weapons we don't need for threats we don't have.

When Russia was known as the USSR they had a population of 289 million, today Russia has only 140 million. As compared to Russia, and really the world, America has an incredible numerical and technological military advantage across the spectrum.

The old USSR had a navy of over 600 ships, today? Less than 350. In fact, Russia only has one aircraft carrier, America has twenty. Destroyers? America has six times more. Military personnel? America has twice as many.

Now Russia has nearly twice as many tanks, but America has nearly three times more fighter and attack aircraft. In fact, America's attack helicopter fleet is twice as large.

Of course Russia has nukes we have to respect that but we've got more and more submarines. Ultimately for a country who's population is less than Pakistan's, Russia still possesses military might, but it is nowhere near what it had at the height of the Cold War.

America's defense industry ecosystem has to find ways to validate a $598 billion defense budget. Similarly, Putin seeks to project a greatly diminished military power-- on an increasingly shrinking stage. Sure Russia is rearming, but America still spends ten times more. As a military veteran, and much to the disappointment of the US Industrial War Complex, Russia's rearming should not impede America's defense cuts.

Someone should make a map showing NATO expansion after the drawdown in the 90s. From what I can see, NATO and allies increased tension in East Asia and South East Asia with China, South Asia with Modi's India, all over the Islamic world for control of oil, Eastern Europe with Russia and even against its own citizen with cutback of rights.

My neighbor worked on Star Wars at Lockheed Sunnyvale, and a test-firing out on Kwajalein island, and then worked on the airborne laser at Edwards AFB.  (That's all I'll say.)  White Sands Missile base near Las Cruces NM has a museum with info about the USAF laser program, incl. a thick titanium block that the laser penetrated in fractions of a second.  Our technologies are far superior to the Russians' versions.

Do you remember when Clinton sent two carrier battle groups in to the Taiwan Straits, in the '90's? At the time the Chinese were threatening Taiwan.
Missile technology, available to both Russia and China would make that impossible today. While carriers are not obsoleted like battleships, their usefulness is increasingly constrained but not their expense. The new carrier, you speak of, tries to offset some of the disadvantages but at increasing expense. The B2 has it's own problems, which is why few were built and a new bomber is under consideration but not being built. Do you know we still have 68 B52's? I believe the F18 came into service in the last century.
The Russian Armata tank is way more advanced than our Abrams and will fully populate their forces by 2020.
There is a lot of technological obsolescence in the US military since much of it was designed in the Reagan era. Maintaining this old stuff costs a lot and detracts from investment. New stuff takes a long time to design and build.
Hence we will go through a period of relative technological weakness. We should try to make that as short as possible.
Repeating the shibboleths that some writers do, will make that harder.

We have the airborne laser in development, the Aegis fleet-based and ground radars, PAC-3 anti-missiles, also Aurora, the J-35, the Osprey, the F-22 in forward bases, millimeter microwave technology for anti-personnel use, the low-profile littoral combat ship, an LCAC fleet, and the Super Hornet 18s, Hawkeyes, E-6 jammers, etc.  The A-10 is being kept in service, too.

A lot of the stuff Russia is buying is new and with more capability than the Reagan era equipment we have. I think it would make for a better comparison if commenters were able to cite Russian military investment vs. US military investment rather than the absolute dollars of our military budget vs some non-comparable number for the Russian.
When I observe news about our military I look for new stuff but there is precious little of it beyond the F35 and one new destroyer.

yep
because the US IS the progressive humanity now, as once the USSR was.
Hope it ends up the same way.
That is, only America has the right to a modern army and military conflicts around the world? :)
Our military spending is over ten times larger than Russia's, which makes Russia's nuclear weapons the great equalizer among unequals. Now that is scary.
We created Putin. Enjoy him.

Libya (1986) 17. El Salvador (1980) 18. Nicaragua (1980s) 19. Panama (1989) 20. Iraq (1991-1999) 21. Sudan (1998) 22. Afghanistan (1998) 23. Yugoslavia (1999) 24. Afghanistan (2001) 25. I would not agree with this judgement. Rationally and consistently destabilizing and destroying economy by eliminating small and medium businesses via extremely complicated and stifling policies and taxes while being ready to discuss issues to later ignore the conclusions sounds like the only way to make your judgement fit the case.
Many thanks, Greg!  I'd hoped out tax monies were being put to good use, and your list proves it.
most dangerous Bear in the forest

I am from Russia.
I have not thought of before, that in the US there are people who think like you. Your (USA) press lying for sure.

Russia has, for many hundreds of years, seen itself surrounded by enemies.

What do they have to fear today? Well, the US and NATO have expanded right up to Russia's borders. Obama keeps sending military units to Eastern Europe (as tripwires rather than actual threats but, at a minimum, he is daring the Russians), in the Ukraine the US backed a coup that ousted a Russia-friendly regime that was replaced by a government as corrupt as Wall Street, in Turkey we sat quietly by while the Turks shot down a Russian attack plane with an F-16 the US paid for and on and on.

Think how the US would react if Russia were acting similarly in the Western Hemisphere.

If Obama keeps poking that bear in the eye with a sharp stick, should we be surprised if it shows its teeth and claws? Wouldn't we?

65 degrees up here in Vermont today. No snow on the ground. Streams are roaring as if it is spring. Great for a long hike in the woods. Bears and other hibernating animals must be vastly confused. I am not confused, just scared of what we have done and what is to come.
